body.p: As key drivers of “green energy,” solar cells are omnipresent in our society. Most everyday consumers are familiar with the sight of monolithic black panels that serve as the flagship standard of this technology. These crystalline silicon materials, despite offering high power-conversion efficiencies, are, nevertheless, expensive, and are too rigid to be used in flexible thin-film devices. The transition-metal dichalcogenide (TMD) material family, which includes metal sulfides, selenides, and tellurides, has been receiving increased interest as a viable alternative that may meet the demands of these applications. The materials properties of TMDs are more conducive to flexible and transparent applications, such as wearable or aerospace electronics. However, for this technology to challenge the dominance of silicon solar cells, its power-conversion efficiency (PCE) metric, which has been sitting around 2%, needs an order-of-magnitude boost to compete with the 30% PCE levels that state-of-the-art photovoltaics offer.

Comprehensive redesign of the TMD photovoltaic cell and its assembly into the circuit that generates energy from sunlight offers a viable opportunity to achieve this breakthrough. A research team from Stanford University, in collaboration with colleagues from Korea’s Sungkyunkwan University, successfully accomplished this feat and delivered a record 5.1% PCE. The team was led by Krishna Saraswat and Eric Pop, and the first authors of the resulting publication were Koosha Nassiri Nazif and Alwin Daus. The article appeared in a recent issue of Nature Communications (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-27195-7).

To accomplish this breakthrough, the team first focused on the challenge of constructing a metal-to-semiconductor (Schottky) junction between the semiconductor material and current collectors, which transfer charge from the photovoltaic cell to the electrical circuit. Traditional metallic contacts with TMDs lock the intrinsic energy level of the junction at a certain level (Fermi level pinning), which limits the amount of current flow that these devices can generate. Instead, this research team used wet transfer of graphene contacts onto the TMD tungsten diselenide (WSe2) to form a damage-free van der Waals interface. This helped mitigate the Fermi level pinning effect and led to a potential of approximately 0.5 V.

Next, the researchers overcame traditional chemical doping limitations in TMDs that are necessary to tune their energy bands and enable photovoltaic energy harvesting. The researchers used damage-free molybdenum oxide (MoOx) electron beam evaporation, which positively doped graphene, and capped the top surfaces of the TMD. This increased the operating open-circuit potential of the solar cell by 0.16 V. The MoOx additionally acted as an antireflective coating that increased the absorbance of the incident light, and, therefore, increased the short-circuit current of the photovoltaic cell.

Finally, to fabricate the proof-of-concept solar cell, the researchers used a direct transfer of the photovoltaic circuit onto a 5-µm-thick polyimide substrate. The team demonstrated the function and scalability of their proof-of-concept WSe2 solar cell by wrapping this optically transparent film around an 8-mm metal cylinder. The film bent with a 4-mm curvature radius without any negative impact on its current–voltage characteristics during light energy harvesting.

The photovoltaic material optimized by the research group was able to harvest energy from the entire visible wavelength spectrum and absorb 55% of incident light. Due to the team’s top-to-bottom optimization of this solar cell it yielded a 4.4 W/g power density—a 100× increase over the current record for TMD photovoltaics. But this is not the end of the road for this material. The team developed theoretical balance models, which estimate that absorption efficiencies of 80% are feasible by further increasing MoOx thickness from its current 10-nm level up to 70 nm. The subsequent power densities and PCE values could reach, respectively, 46 W/g and 27%. These metrics would easily transcend all comparable thin-film photovoltaic materials and usher in breakthrough capabilities for flexible or wearable energy-harvesting systems.

Saraswat told MRS Bulletin, “This work has made a case for adopting TMDs as next-generation photovoltaic materials, and has provided novel and scalable solutions for their challenges, leading to record high performance on par with prevailing thin-film solar technologies. Ultimately, we project that future TMD solar cells on very thin substrates and with higher efficiencies could potentially achieve an additional 10× increase in specific power, creating game-changing opportunities in a broad range of industries, from aerospace to wearable and implantable electronics.”
